result.title: Some notes about programming contest.
result.content:
1) Implementation is important.

This is a 'programming' contest, not a math contest. There are problems that require no algorithm but difficult implementations. (Example: Last year's ACM-ICPC 'Bowling' which very few teams solved.)

2) Language Java is slower, but almost all problems are designed so that both languages have solutions.

Java can use BigInteger class, which it's hard to implement in C++ during contest.

Most people on online programming contests use C++.

There are some problems which you need extra optimization on algorithm when using Java.

IMO, learn both. Both are important anyway.

3) List of online contests.

  • TopCoder : Programming contest

    Pro: No need to write I/O.

    Con: Problems are not very close to ACM-ICPC. Cannot practice I/O.

  • SPOJ, UVa, PKU OJ ... : Websites with bunch of problems.

    Pro: Very close to ACM-ICPC style.

    Con: They don't show the test case you failed, so you will need to debug for days.

  • Project Euler : Websites with bunch of math problems.

    Pro: Any language. No time limit. Fun.

    Con: Not close to ACM-ICPC at all. I just wanted to list this since I like it a lot :)
